title: A social media post about a traveler’s ‘masterclass in boundaries’ on a flight out of Maine goes viral
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: A social media post from a flight departing Maine about setting boundaries has gone viral with 31,000 likes.
The post details a woman's direct response when a male passenger invaded her personal space on a flight.
The incident spurred discussions on social media, with many sharing personal stories of boundary issues during travel.

title: Is your home ready for this winter?
author: Zipporah Osei
bullets: Boston's snowfall exceeds 60 inches this winter, marking the first time since 'Snowmageddon' in 2015.
The Winter Home Guide offers tips on managing icy roofs, snow-packed driveways, and frozen gardens.
Residents can sign up for a midwinter home survival kit email with seasonal hacks and practical advice.

title: What Boston meteorologists are saying about the timing and impacts of Wednesday’s snow
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Southern New England will see 1-3 inches of snow Wednesday morning, starting between 5 to 8 a.m.
Snow will mix with rain along the south coast, clearing around 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. from west to east.
Meteorologists warn of slick roads and reduced visibility, with conditions improving by midday.

title: Some changes are in store for Kendall Square Cinema
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Kendall Square Cinema in Cambridge will begin renovations in March, including larger screens and luxury recliners.
The renovations will combine two auditoriums, add a full-service bar, and introduce a video arcade area.
Renovations are expected to conclude by late summer, continuing to cater to both indie and commercial film audiences.

title: View Boston to shutter observatory restaurants, cut 79 jobs
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: View Boston is closing its observatory restaurants at Prudential Center and laying off 79 employees to focus on private events.
The restaurant closures at View Boston include the Beacon and Stratus rooftop bar, effective April 21, as part of business restructuring.
The Prudential Tower observatory refurbishment, completed for $182 million in 2023, will shift to provide expanded event spaces and new offerings.

title: Alex Cora was impressed by Ranger Suarez in limited spring training debut for Red Sox
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Ranger Suarez made his spring training debut for the Red Sox, signing a five-year, $130 million contract.
Red Sox manager Alex Cora praised Suarez's competitive nature despite giving up two runs in 1 2/3 innings.
Suarez is preparing to pitch for Team Venezuela in the World Baseball Classic, starting workouts early for it.

title: Local obituary: Madelyn Eitas, Rochester 11-year-old
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Madelyn Eitas, an 11-year-old from Rochester, passed away on February 19 during a family vacation.
Madelyn was known for her leadership, kindness, and ability to bring people together at social events and sports games.
A funeral will be held at Saint Patrick Church in Wareham on February 28, followed by a celebration on March 1.

title: Boston couple’s wedding disrupted by blizzard — they got married anyway
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Maddie McNamara and Drew Baker married at the Newbury Hotel after a blizzard canceled their Boston Public Library wedding.
The couple exchanged vows in a hotel suite with only an officiant, his fiancée, and photographer present.
They captured wedding portraits in a snow-covered Newbury Street, embracing the blizzard for a unique wedding memory.

title: Dave Epstein: How long will it take for all this snow to melt?
author: David Epstein
bullets: Eastern Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut experience some of the highest snow levels on record this February.
Boston area received about 60 inches of snow, with Providence accumulating approximately 70 inches this season.
Melting could be gradual; above-freezing temperatures and strong sun aid snow reduction, minimizing flood risks.

title: After calling police, Conn. man kills terminally ill wife and then himself
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: John Ezzell called 911 before killing his terminally ill wife, Christine, and himself in Plainfield, Connecticut.
Police discovered John and Christine Ezzell dead from gunshot wounds at their Kate Downing Road home.
The incident is classified as isolated with no public threat, per the Plainfield Police Department.
